Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208,.proposition: The Plaintiff seeks to modify the current custody order to remove the midweek overnight visitation and to amend the weekend schedule to accommodate the increased distance between the parties.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Plaintiff avers that there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances since the entry of the original custody order. The Defendant now intends to move to New Hampshire for a job opportunity, which will significantly impact the current custody arrangement. The Defendant's proposed move to New Hampshire, approximately ninety minutes away, will impose undue burden and hardship on the minor child, Emily Johnson. The midweek overnight visits as currently ordered will require lengthy commutes and disrupt Emily's school schedule and extracurricular activities.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether a proposed relocation approximately ninety minutes away (within New England) constitutes a substantial and material change that would unduly burden a child and disrupt an existing custody/visitation schedule. Yannas addresses a very different issue: interstate/international removal of children by the custodial parent and articulates the ‘real advantage’ standard for permitting removal, not the standard for modifying an existing custody/visitation order based on a relatively short-distance move. The case therefore does not provide authority for the specific claimed proposition about hardship from a 90‑minute relocation and midweek visitation burdens.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices… An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change… the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent… The interest of the custodial parent in moving must also be assessed… In this process, the first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a ‘real advantage.’”

Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.proposition: The Plaintiff avers that there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances since the entry of the original custody order. The Defendant now intends to move to New Hampshire for a job opportunity, which will significantly impact the current custody arrangement. The Defendant's proposed move to New Hampshire, approximately ninety minutes away, will impose undue burden and hardship on the minor child, Emily Johnson. The midweek overnight visits as currently ordered will require lengthy commutes and disrupt Emily's school schedule and extracurricular activities.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether a planned relocation (about ninety minutes away) and its effect on an existing custody/visitation schedule constitutes a substantial and material change in circumstances and an undue burden on the child. Bower v. Bournay-Bower does not address relocation, substantial/material change, or the practical burdens of travel on a parenting-time schedule. Instead, it addresses the probate court’s inherent authority (and limits) to appoint a parenting coordinator and the unlawful delegation of judicial authority. It therefore does not provide authority for the relocation/change-in-circumstances proposition.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.relevant_excerpt: By statute, if a party seeks a modification of a final judgment of divorce, a judge may make a judgment modifying his or her earlier judgment provided the judge finds that “a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.” G. L. c. 208, § 28. No such standard governs the parent coordinator in the order at issue in this case.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Plaintiff avers that there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances since the entry of the original custody order. The Defendant now intends to move to New Hampshire for a job opportunity, which will significantly impact the current custody arrangement. The Defendant's proposed move to New Hampshire, approximately ninety minutes away, will impose undue burden and hardship on the minor child, Emily Johnson. The midweek overnight visits as currently ordered will require lengthy commutes and disrupt Emily's school schedule and extracurricular activities.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recognizes that a parental relocation that significantly increases distance and travel burdens can constitute a substantial change of circumstances and must be evaluated under a best-interests standard, focusing on impacts to the child’s schooling, daily schedule, and the feasibility of the existing shared physical custody arrangement. The Court quotes the ALI Principles that relocation is a substantial change when it ‘significantly impairs’ a parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities and emphasizes how greater travel time between homes and schools and other burdens of distance can negatively affect the child. Although the specific distances differ, the case clearly supports using a relocation and its commuting burdens as grounds to claim a material change in circumstances affecting custody and visitation.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part:
‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising…’ …
‘It is a question for a judge, taking into account all of the facts, whether an increase in travel time between households and schools brought about by removal, and other burdens of distance, will significantly impair either parent’s ability to exercise existing responsibilities, and ultimately whether removal is in a child’s best interests.’

Osborne v. Osborne, 384 Mass. 591 (1981).proposition: The Plaintiff avers that there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances since the entry of the original custody order. The Defendant now intends to move to New Hampshire for a job opportunity, which will significantly impact the current custody arrangement. The Defendant's proposed move to New Hampshire, approximately ninety minutes away, will impose undue burden and hardship on the minor child, Emily Johnson. The midweek overnight visits as currently ordered will require lengthy commutes and disrupt Emily's school schedule and extracurricular activities.
Osborne v. Osborne, 384 Mass. 591 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion in Osborne v. Osborne deals solely with the validity and effect of an antenuptial agreement and related property and alimony issues in a divorce. It does not address child custody, standards for modification of custody orders, the impact of a parent’s relocation, or burdens on a child’s visitation schedule. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition that a proposed move 90 minutes away constitutes a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting an existing custody arrangement.

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).proposition: The Plaintiff avers that there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances since the entry of the original custody order. The Defendant now intends to move to New Hampshire for a job opportunity, which will significantly impact the current custody arrangement. The Defendant's proposed move to New Hampshire, approximately ninety minutes away, will impose undue burden and hardship on the minor child, Emily Johnson. The midweek overnight visits as currently ordered will require lengthy commutes and disrupt Emily's school schedule and extracurricular activities.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: Felton v. Felton deals with modification of visitation based on alleged religious harm to the children, not relocation or geographic moves by a custodial or noncustodial parent. While it restates the general requirement of a ‘material change of circumstances’ to modify a custody‑related judgment, it does not involve or analyze relocation, burdens of travel, or disruption of school schedules as a basis for modification. Using this case to support a proposition about a move to New Hampshire materially affecting custody/visitation is therefore inapposite.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “We apply the words of Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981), a case seeking modification of alimony and child support provisions in a divorce judgment, to the present case, also demanding modification of a divorce judgment, although as to a different subject matter: ‘To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.’”

Anzalone v. Anzalone, 403 Mass. 146 (198.proposition: The Plaintiff avers that there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances since the entry of the original custody order. The Defendant now intends to move to New Hampshire for a job opportunity, which will significantly impact the current custody arrangement. The Defendant's proposed move to New Hampshire, approximately ninety minutes away, will impose undue burden and hardship on the minor child, Emily Johnson. The midweek overnight visits as currently ordered will require lengthy commutes and disrupt Emily's school schedule and extracurricular activities.
Anzalone v. Anzalone, 403 Mass. 146 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion in Anzalone v. Anzalone concerns the admissibility of uncounseled prior criminal convictions in sexually dangerous person commitment proceedings under G.L. c. 123A. It does not involve child custody, relocation of a parent, modifications of custody orders, or burdens imposed on a child’s visitation schedule. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that a parent’s move ninety minutes away constitutes a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting custody or visitation arrangements.
Anzalone v. Anzalone, 403 Mass. 146 (198.relevant_excerpt: In c. 123A proceedings the central issue is whether the respondent is an SDP. Chapter 123A defines an SDP as “any person whose misconduct in sexual matters indicates a general lack of power to control his sexual impulses, as evidenced by repetitive or compulsive sexual misconduct… and who, as a result, is likely to attack or otherwise inflict injury…” … We conclude that it is a violation of due process rights to introduce prior convictions in evidence in a c. 123A proceeding without a showing regarding the respondent’s representation by counsel in the prior proceedings.

Moriarty v. Stone, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 151.raw_text: Moriarty v. Stone, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 151 (1996)
Moriarty v. Stone, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 151.proposition: The Plaintiff avers that there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances since the entry of the original custody order. The Defendant now intends to move to New Hampshire for a job opportunity, which will significantly impact the current custody arrangement. The Defendant's proposed move to New Hampshire, approximately ninety minutes away, will impose undue burden and hardship on the minor child, Emily Johnson. The midweek overnight visits as currently ordered will require lengthy commutes and disrupt Emily's school schedule and extracurricular activities.
Moriarty v. Stone, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 151.support_reasoning: The opinion in Moriarty v. Stone is a divorce and property division case that does not involve child custody, relocation of a custodial parent, or modification of a custody/visitation order. It contains no discussion of what constitutes a substantial and material change in circumstances for custody purposes, nor any analysis of the impact of a proposed move on a child’s visitation schedule. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition concerning a relocation to New Hampshire affecting a child’s midweek visits and school schedule.
Moriarty v. Stone, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 151.relevant_excerpt: We summarize the pertinent facts found by the master and adopted by the judge. This was an eight-year marriage (1986-1994) preceded by a ten-year period (1976-1986) during which the parties lived together. The parties had no children.

Van Arsdale v. Van Arsdale, 79 Mass. App.raw_text: Van Arsdale v. Van Arsdale, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 293 (2011)
Van Arsdale v. Van Arsdale, 79 Mass. App.proposition: The Plaintiff avers that there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances since the entry of the original custody order. The Defendant now intends to move to New Hampshire for a job opportunity, which will significantly impact the current custody arrangement. The Defendant's proposed move to New Hampshire, approximately ninety minutes away, will impose undue burden and hardship on the minor child, Emily Johnson. The midweek overnight visits as currently ordered will require lengthy commutes and disrupt Emily's school schedule and extracurricular activities.
Van Arsdale v. Van Arsdale, 79 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion in Van Arsdale v. Van Arsdale is a criminal case about drug offenses, search warrants, and suppression of evidence. It does not address family law, custody orders, relocation of a parent, or the impact of a move on a child’s schedule or best interests. Therefore, it provides no authority for the claimed proposition about a substantial and material change in custody circumstances due to a parent’s move to New Hampshire.
Van Arsdale v. Van Arsdale, 79 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: The defendant appeals his convictions of various drug offenses, arguing (1) his motion to suppress was erroneously denied, and (2) Melendez-Diaz v. Massachusetts, 129 S. Ct. 2527 (2009), requires reversal of his conviction of trafficking in oxycodone. Because we agree that the judge should have allowed the motion to suppress, we vacate all but one of the defendant’s convictions.

Redding v. Redding, 398 Mass. 586 (1986).proposition: The Plaintiff avers that there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances since the entry of the original custody order. The Defendant now intends to move to New Hampshire for a job opportunity, which will significantly impact the current custody arrangement. The Defendant's proposed move to New Hampshire, approximately ninety minutes away, will impose undue burden and hardship on the minor child, Emily Johnson. The midweek overnight visits as currently ordered will require lengthy commutes and disrupt Emily's school schedule and extracurricular activities.
Redding v. Redding, 398 Mass. 586 (1986).case_name: Blue Cross of Massachusetts, Inc. v. Travaline
Redding v. Redding, 398 Mass. 586 (1986).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns an insurer’s subrogation rights and whether a tort plaintiff’s attorney has a duty to reimburse the insurer from settlement proceeds. It does not address child custody, relocation of a custodial parent, substantial and material change in circumstances, or the impact of a move on a child’s visitation schedule. Therefore it provides no authority for the claimed custody/relocation proposition and is being miscited.
Redding v. Redding, 398 Mass. 586 (1986).relevant_excerpt: “1. Applicability of General Exch. Ins. Corp. v. Driscoll. The judge stated in his memorandum of decision that he considered himself bound by this court’s opinion in General Exch. Ins. Corp. v. Driscoll, 315 Mass. 360 (1944), to grant summary judgment for Blue Cross/Blue Shield… In ordering the entry of judgment for Mr. Travaline, we express no opinion on the validity of any claim which Blue Cross/Blue Shield might bring directly against the Darishes on the basis of the subrogation provision…”
